content:
The "Fix Gun Checks Act of 2015" ensures that individuals prohibited from buying a gun are listed in the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. TITLE II--REQUIRING A BACKGROUND CHECK FOR EVERY FIREARM SALE
Sec. 201. Purpose.
Sec. 202. Firearms transfers.
Sec. 203. Lost and stolen reporting. TITLE I--ENSURING THAT ALL INDIVIDUALS WHO SHOULD BE PROHIBITED FROM BUYING A GUN ARE LISTED IN THE NATIONAL INSTANT CRIMINAL BACKGROUND CHECK SYSTEM. Penalties for states that do not make data electronically available to the system. Section 102(b) of the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 is amended to require the Attorney General, in coordination with states, to establish a plan for maximum coordination and automation of reporting records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The plan must include annual benchmarks for assessing implementation. The Attorney General, in coordination with states, must establish a plan for maximum coordination and automation of reporting records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The plan includes annual benchmarks for assessing implementation. Penalties for noncompliance involve withholding a percentage of funds allocated to a State under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act if benchmarks are not met. The plan includes annual benchmarks for assessing implementation, with penalties for noncompliance involving withholding funds if benchmarks are not met. Federal agencies must certify that they have submitted all records of individuals prohibited from buying firearms to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System under federal law. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act requires federal agencies to certify and report semiannually to the Attorney General on providing pertinent information on individuals prohibited from buying firearms. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act mandates federal agencies to certify and report biannually to the Attorney General regarding information on individuals prohibited from purchasing firearms. The certification must be submitted by July 31 for records from January 1 to June 30, and by January 31 for records from July 1 to December 31. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act requires federal agencies to certify and report biannually to the Attorney General on individuals prohibited from buying firearms. The certification should include the number of records showing individuals falling under the categories in section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act mandates federal agencies to certify and report biannually to the Attorney General on individuals prohibited from purchasing firearms, including the total number of records provided to the Attorney General. SEC. 103. ADJUDICATED AS A MENTAL DEFECTIVE. The term 'adjudicated as a mental defective' is defined as a court order for a person to receive mental health services, excluding substance abuse testing. The term 'committed to a mental institution' is also clarified. The term 'committed to a mental institution' is defined in accordance with federal regulations. Individuals adjudicated as mentally defective before a specified date cannot seek relief from disability under the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007. Amendments to the Act include changes to mental health terms. The terms 'adjudicated as a mental defective' and 'committed to a mental institution' have specific meanings as defined in federal regulations. These terms will have the same meanings as before the Fix Gun Checks Act of 2015 for a 2-year period after its enactment. SEC. 104 of the Brady Handgun Violence Protection Act clarifies that federal court information must be made available to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will perform the functions of the head of the department or agency for any request, submission, or notification. Title II aims to require background checks for all firearm sales and transfers, extending the Brady Law procedures to cover all transactions. Title II of the United States Code, Section 922, is amended to prohibit the transfer of firearms by unlicensed individuals to other unlicensed individuals, defining the term "chief law enforcement officer" and specifying who it includes. Title II of the United States Code, Section 922, prohibits unlicensed individuals from transferring firearms to others unless a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer is involved. Exceptions include transfers to law enforcement agencies/officers and gifts between spouses or family members. Exceptions to the prohibition on unlicensed individuals transferring firearms include transfers between family members, transfers upon death, temporary transfers to prevent harm, transfers approved by the Attorney General, and temporary transfers if the transferor has no reason to believe the firearm will be used in a crime. The transfer of firearms by unlicensed individuals is allowed in specific circumstances, such as at shooting ranges, while hunting or in the presence of the transferor. The amendment made by subsection (a)(4) shall take effect 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, modifying sections 925A and 922(s) of the title. SEC. 203 of the amendment to title 18, United States Code, requires individuals who lawfully possess a firearm involved in interstate commerce to report any theft or loss of the firearm within 48 hours to the Attorney General and local authorities. Failure to comply will result in penalties under Section 924(a)(1)(B).
